@ellenhuet AND it flips the responsibility. Today = Whomever asks needs to program API. Future = Whomever is asked is expected to interpret.
@ellenhuet Exactly and super interesting observation. This is still the biggest barrier  for general software integration. Knowing the API.
@ellenhuet People do this all the time with e.g. colleagues. "Amy, get Steven and I together for a quick 20 min chat Tuesday morning please"
@SiVola @ellenhuet I'm making a bet (and I could certainly be wrong) that the scheduling solution of the future is one of intelligent agents
@SiVola @ellenhuet AND shared calendars doesn't take my preferences into consideration. Just because I am free doesn't mean I want to meet.
@SiVola @ellenhuet This is hard on shared calendars. Ellen could be on MS Exchange, Paolo on Google Cal and I could be running on iCloud.
@SiVola @ellenhuet "Amy, please set up a meeting with Ellen and Paolo, first week of June in the afternoon at x.ai HQ".
@ellenhuet Initially a little clunky. Sure. But going from e.g. Python Code to US English is a massive achievement. I'm biased of course :-)
@ellenhuet Communication between applications in the past required traditional APIs. I am thrilled to see a future based on Natural Language

Who's ‚Ä¶
@suzywillow @jonathanbowden @rrhoover @ProductHunt @xdotai @agarwala x.ai FTW :-)
@luisobo We would all be a fools to disagree with @stephen_wolfram (huge fan). I DO believe "English" is the most likely short term outcome.
@qxip I think the interesting point is that you won't see traditional API's as we known them today, but AI's writing English to other AI's.
@qxip Not English per say, but natural language. So pick any one of the +6000 languages on earth :-)
@MichaelTerwindt ... it's a fascinating topic :-)
@MichaelTerwindt this indicate that we communicate with AI's from a human viewpoint and as such should see them adopt other human qualities.
@MichaelTerwindt "English" representing natural language and the idea that we did not create a "syntax" to communicate with our AI's.
@JLBex say you asked Amy @xdotai to schedule a meeting with COKE. She should ask your AI driven travel agent when you arrive in ATL first.
@JLBex that is almost inevitable, but I think that the most dramatic impact arrives when Agents start to speak to each other autonomously.
@bmann This is a great discussion and you should pop by the @xdotai office for a diet coke next time you are in the city! :-)
@bmann If I want to increase agent success (short term) I communicate in English. No immediate benefit in betting on machine in other end.
@bmann And in the current phase, using existing protocols, such as "Email", we simply don't know if the other agent is a Human or Machine.
@bmann Agree! But I also think initial friction to create an agent communication standard across verticals is too high for that to happen
AI's communicating in natural language, say English, to other Agents, suggest that two AI agents will initially speak English to each other.
As humans command their AI's in English and as those AI's reach out to other agents (Human or AI) they'll have to do so in English as well.
@jkreindler we talk about this all time time at @xdotai and my teammate @annakelsey's primary charter is to make Amy as human as possible!
As we communicate with our AI's in English, it also seems obvious to me that we would want to purposefully humanize them. Why not!?
..and it seems to me that the best communication method between humans and AI's would natural language, say English, and not some new syntax
I believe that the next software application paradigm will consist primarily of intelligent agents, AIs. The future can't be about more Apps
"Impossible is just a big word thrown around by small men. It's not a fact. It‚Äôs an opinion. Impossible is not a declaration. It‚Äôs a dare!"
